project_description: The Nautical Chart Update Pilot Project was an opportunity for individuals and local groups, such as boating clubs, to help evaluate and improve information on NOAA electronic navigational charts (NOAA ENC®). Citizen scientists were encouraged to submit annual reports addressing a specific ENC or area. These reports were evaluated by NOAA cartographers for potential chart updates.
keywords: Office of Coast Survey, hydrography, cartography
fields_of_science: Geography, Ocean/water and marine
participation_tasks: Geolocation, Measurement, Observation
project_goals: This project will help improve the accuracy of NOAA charts and publications.
refined_description:
Skills required: Proficiency in using NOAA electronic navigational charts (NOAA ENC®) and knowledge of maritime navigation. 
Levels of expertise needed: Intermediate to advanced knowledge in cartography and navigational charting. 
Fields of research: Marine navigation and chart updates. 
Other important aspects: Ability to evaluate and report on specific ENC or area, participation as citizen scientists, and collaboration with local boating clubs or individuals.

project_description: It’s notoriously difficult to research winter precipitation in the mountains as precipitation phase (rain, snow, or mixed) can vary over the course of minutes and across short distances. Human observers are our best resource for discovering how rain and snow vary in time and space. Mountain Rain or Snow is a citizen science project devoted to collecting real-time observations of precipitation phase.
fields_of_science: Climate and weather, Geology and earth science, Nature and outdoors
participant_age: Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Classification or Tagging, Geolocation, Identification, Observation
project_goals: Crowdsourced reports of rain, snow, and mixed precipitation will help us and other scientists improve remote sensing products and hydrologic models to better estimate what type of precipitation falls during winter storms.
refined_description:
Skills required: Basic knowledge of weather and precipitation, ability to make observations and record data accurately.
Levels of expertise needed: No specific expertise required, open to anyone interested in contributing observations.
Fields of research: Weather, precipitation, climate change.
Other important aspects: Real-time data collection, citizen science involvement, focus on mountain regions and their unique precipitation patterns.

project_description: Do you ever find yourself gazing up at the blue sky and the tapestries of clouds passing by--sometimes thin and wispy, other times thick and puffy, often in shapes that you could swear are objects you recognize? Have you ever wondered what it would be like to lie down in your astronaut suit on the surface of Mars and look up at clouds in the Martian sky? While no humans have done so yet, we know that clouds are a regular phenomenon in Mars's atmosphere. With the help of telescopes, orbiters, and our rovers' eyes, we've been able to spot them for some time. Clouds are an important area of research on Mars (and on Earth, too) because of their feedback on the climate -- they can reflect incoming sunlight which has a cooling effect and absorb the planet's outgoing infrared radiation which has a warming effect. In fact, clouds may have played a crucial role in sustaining a warm atmosphere on early Mars enabling liquid water to flow and carve out channels we see in the geology today. Whereas Earth clouds are made of liquid water, the cold temperatures and low pressures of Mars today (which prevent liquid water) allow water-ice and carbon-dioxide ice clouds to form. The Mars Climate Sounder, an instrument on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, is able to see clouds at very high altitudes (>30 miles) in the Martian atmosphere and our goal is to map them to better understand their composition and how they form. But we need your help!
fields_of_science: Astronomy and space, Chemistry, Climate and weather, Physics
participant_age: Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Annotation, Data Analysis, Identification
project_goals: By creating a database of clouds high in Mars's atmosphere we can better understand how clouds form on Mars, what they're made of, and how they affect the climate.
refined_description:
Skills required: Knowledge of telescopes, orbiters, and rovers; expertise in cloud research and climate feedback; ability to analyze data from instruments like Mars Climate Sounder; collaboration and communication skills.
Levels of expertise needed: Advanced knowledge of Mars, planetary science, and atmospheric processes; proficiency in data analysis and interpretation.
Fields of research: Mars atmospheric science, cloud formation and composition, climate feedback mechanisms.
Other important aspects: Collaboration with NASA and other scientific institutions; utilizing telescopes, orbiters, and rovers to gather data; mapping and understanding the role of clouds in Mars' climate and geological features.

project_description: A project to join the amateur radio and professional space science communities together for mutual benefit.
fields_of_science: Astronomy and space, Climate and weather, Computers and technology, Education, Geology and earth science, Physics
agency_sponsor: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), National Science Foundation (NSF)
participant_age: Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Targeted group, Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Audio or Video Recording, Classification or Tagging, Data Analysis, Identification, Learning, Measurement, Observation, Problem Solving
project_goals: The objectives of HamSCI are to (1) advance scientific research and understanding through amateur radio activities, (2) encourage the development of new technologies to support this research, and (3) provide educational opportunities for the amateur community and the general public.
refined_description:
Skills required: Strong knowledge of amateur radio and space science, effective communication and collaboration skills.
Levels of expertise: Proficient understanding of amateur radio and space science principles.
Fields of research: Amateur radio technology, space science, mutual benefits of collaboration.
Other important aspects: Strong networking and relationship-building abilities, understanding of project management principles.

project_description: In response to a particularly bad red tide on the Gulf coast of Florida, a group of commercial and recreational fishermen started to collect data during fishing trips. The volunteers take an instrument and take water column profiles in several locations which are turned into environmental bulletins.
fields_of_science: Chemistry, Disaster response, Ecology and environment, Nature and outdoors, Ocean/water and marine
participation_tasks: Measurement, Observation, Site Selection and/or Description
project_goals: To collect data about offshore and nearshore conditions before, during and after red tides on the Gulf coast of Florida. We are particularly interested in monitoring the development of hypoxic (low oxygen) areas that can be devastating to marine life. The data are used to make fishery management decisions and being used to develop hypoxia forecasting capabilities.
refined_description:
Skills required: Data collection, instrument operation, water column profiling, reporting.
Levels of expertise needed: Intermediate knowledge in marine ecosystem, proficiency in data analysis and reporting.
Fields of research: Marine biology, environmental science.
Other important aspects: Knowledge of red tides, experience in fishing, ability to work independently and as part of a team.

project_name: Kenai River Baseline Water Quality Monitoring
project_description: Kenai Watershed Forum has worked with community partners since the year 2000 to monitor water quality throughout the Kenai River Watershed.
fields_of_science: Ecology and environment
agency_sponsor: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Forest Service (USFS)
participation_tasks: Measurement, Observation
project_goals: The Baseline Water Quality Monitoring Program project uses data to identify trends in and develop solutions for water quality challenges in Alaska's most popular river.
refined_description:
Skills required: Knowledge in water quality monitoring, ability to work with community partners, data analysis.
Levels of expertise needed: Intermediate level of understanding in water quality monitoring and research.
Fields of research: Water quality, environmental science.
Other important aspects: Collaboration with community partners, data collection and analysis, long-term monitoring.

project_description: There is currently not a nationwide beach grain size database, which limits large-scale coastal studies. SandSnap is a research initiative to amass a nationwide beach sand grain size database with the help of citizen scientists taking photos of the beach sand with their smart phones. This grain size information will be used by researchers and local officials to learn more about coastal dynamics and make better management decisions.
fields_of_science: Geology and earth science, Ocean/water and marine
participant_age: Elementary school (6-10), Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Geolocation, Measurement, Observation, Photography, Specimen/Sample Collection
project_goals: The goal of this project is to build a database of coastal sediment characteristics from photos collected by citizen scientists.
refined_description:
Skills required: Photography skills, data management skills. 
Levels of expertise needed: Citizen scientists, no specific expertise required. 
Fields of research: Coastal dynamics, beach management. 
Important aspects: Nationwide coverage, utilization of citizen scientists, large-scale coastal studies.

project_description: You can help us track Hawaiian green sea turtles (honu) by reporting the location where you see turtles with white alpha-numeric markings on their shells. Become a citizen scientist and contribute to a valuable source of data for sea turtles in Hawai‘i!
fields_of_science: Animals, Biology, Ecology and environment, Nature and outdoors, Ocean/water and marine
agency_sponsor: Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
geographic_scope: Main Hawaiian Islands; Oahu, Maui, Lanai, Molokai, Hawaii, Kauai, Niihau
participant_age: Elementary school (6-10), Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Data Entry, Geolocation, Learning, Observation, Photography
project_goals: This valuable scientific information is used to track recently rehabilitated turtles, resident turtle habitat use, or when nesting turtles return back to their foraging grounds. We also use the data collected from Honu Count to determine the resilience of the Hawaiian green sea turtle in the face of climate change.
refined_description:
Skills required: Observation, reporting, and data recording skills.
Levels of expertise needed: No specific expertise required, open to citizen scientists.
Fields of research: Marine biology, conservation biology, and ecology.
Other important aspects: Familiarity with Hawaiian green sea turtles and their markings, ability to accurately identify and report location of turtles.

project_description: When you look up into the night sky, do you wonder what's out there beyond our solar system? So do we! Come join us in learning more about exoplanets, the worlds that orbit distant stars. You don't need to own a telescope in order to participate. We can give you archived data from robotic telescopes to process with our free EXOTIC software. If you do have a telescope with a tracking mount, we can show you how to observe exoplanets yourself.
fields_of_science: Astronomy and space
participation_tasks: Data Analysis, Learning, Observation, Photography, Sample Analysis
project_goals: With your help, using data from small telescopes, Exoplanet Watch will make the best use of larger telescopes, discover new exoplanets, monitor changes in a star's brightness, and confirm recently discovered exoplanets.
refined_description:
Skills Required: Basic knowledge of astronomy, ability to use data processing software.
Levels of Expertise Needed: Beginner to intermediate in astronomy.
Fields of Research: Exoplanets, distant stars.
Other Important Aspects: Access to robotic telescopes and tracking mount telescopes is preferred but not required.

project_name: Are we alone in the universe?
project_description: Help us answer one of science’s most important questions. The UCLA SETI Group uses the largest fully steerable telescope on Earth to search for evidence of civilizations in our Galaxy. We observe thousands of stars and their planets with the goal of detecting radio transmissions. You will classify signals by matching them to common classes of radio frequency interference. Your classifications will be used to develop artificial intelligence tools to accelerate the search.
fields_of_science: Astronomy and space, Biology, Chemistry, Computers and technology, Physics
participant_age: Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Classification or Tagging, Data Analysis
project_goals: Join the search for extraterrestrial civilizations!
refined_description:
Skills required: Knowledge of radio frequency interference, ability to classify signals, understanding of artificial intelligence tools.

Levels of expertise needed: Intermediate to advanced understanding of radio frequency interference, familiarity with AI tools.

Fields of research: Astronomy, astrophysics, radio astronomy.

Other important aspects: Strong attention to detail, ability to work with large amounts of data.

project_description: Since 1954 the Cooperative Tagging Center has provided free conventional tags to anglers to deploy on Billfish and Tuna species.  The data from this program has been used in the international stock assessments of these Highly Migratory Species.
fields_of_science: Animals, Biology, Ecology and environment, Nature and outdoors, Ocean/water and marine
geographic_scope: Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of Mexico, and adjacent waters
participant_age: Elementary school (6-10), Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Targeted group, Youth/teen (up to 17), Fishermen
participation_tasks: Classification or Tagging, Observation, Specimen/Sample Collection
project_goals: To provide a long-term dataset of HMS species movement and distributions for use in stock assessments.
refined_description:
Skills required: knowledge of fish tagging techniques, data collection and management skills.
Levels of expertise needed: experience in conducting research on Highly Migratory Species, familiarity with stock assessment methods.
Fields of research: fisheries science, marine biology, stock assessment.
Other important aspects: understanding of international fisheries management and conservation, ability to collaborate with anglers and stakeholders.

project_description: The Chesapeake Water Watch is a joint project between the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center (SERC) and the City College of New York (CCNY). Our researchers are developing new ways to use remote sensing to fill in water monitoring gaps. We are partnering with Riverkeepers and individuals like you to collect data with simple-to-use scientific equipment and smartphone applications.
fields_of_science: Astronomy and space, Biology, Chemistry, Climate and weather, Computers and technology, Ecology and environment, Geology and earth science, Nature and outdoors, Ocean/water and marine
geographic_scope: Tidal regions of the Chesapeake Bay
participant_age: Elementary school (6-10), Families, General public, Middle school (11-13), Youth/teen (up to 17)
participation_tasks: Data Analysis, Data Entry, Geolocation, Identification, Learning, Measurement, Observation, Problem Solving, Sample Analysis, Site Selection and/or Description, Specimen/Sample Collection
project_goals: Chesapeake Water Watch seeks to use remote sensing to fill in water monitoring gaps in the Chesapeake Bay.
refined_description:
Skills required: Remote sensing, water monitoring, data collection, use of scientific equipment and smartphone applications.
Levels of expertise needed: Intermediate to advanced knowledge in remote sensing and water monitoring.
Fields of research: Environmental science, water quality, remote sensing.
Important aspects: Collaboration with Riverkeepers and individuals, development of new methods for filling in water monitoring gaps.
